lead_paragraph: It was a charmless stand of scrubby black oak that Louie Myers strode into as dusk settled on Mad River Ridge the other day. But his eyes lit up. They began to dart. He scanned the wood like any animal-world forager, and he smiled. Asked what so captivated him in the sparse growth typical of these remote Northern California mountains, he declared: "I see money. Lots of money. And I don't have to cut down a single tree to get it!"

headline.main: From Necessity, New Forest Industry Rises
